University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. 'A pain in the butt: Understanding the physiology of Campylobacter jejuni inside and outside the host' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/may/a-pain-in-the-butt-understanding-the-physiology-of-campylobacter-jejuni-inside-and-outside-the-host Bennett Lecture Theatre 2 - 26 May 2015, 12:00PM - 01:00PM No publisher User Submitted College:MedBioPsych Magazine:Staff Event:Lecture Magazine:Research 2015-05-26T11:00:00Z UoL Event Launch of 'The Bones of A King: Richard III Rediscovered' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/launch-of-the-bones-of-a-king-richard-iii-rediscovered University of Leicester Bookshop - 21 Mar 2015, 01:00PM - 02:00PM Written by The Grey Friars Research Team here at the University\ufffd\ufffdand Maev Kennedy\ufffd\ufffdfrom The Guardian. The book will be launched at an event at the University of Leicester at 1pm on Saturday 21st March in the University Bookshop with members of the team, as part of a free day of family-friendly activities celebrating the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research, discovery and identification of Richard III. Copies of the book will be available to purchase from the University Bookshop.

]]> No publisher pt91 College:SciEng College:MedBioPsych College:Arts Magazine:Staff Event:Lecture College:SocSci Magazine:Research 2015-03-21T13:00:00Z UoL Event World TB Day https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/world-tb-day Frank & Katherine May Lecture Theatre, Henry Wellcome - 24 Mar 2015, 02:00PM - 05:00PM No publisher User Submitted College:MedBioPsych Event:Conference Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research 2015-03-24T14:00:00Z UoL Event 'Using chemical building blocks for cancer drug discovery' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/using-chemical-building-blocks-for-cancer-drug-discovery Leicester Adult Education College, 2 Wellington St, Leicester City Centre - 27 Mar 2015, 12:00PM - 01:00PM Drug discovery is becoming ever more difficult and expensive which negatively affects how effectively doctors are able to treat cancer. In the past, pharmaceutical companies have tried various ways of changing this situation but none have been as successful as hoped. In the last two decades, a new way of discovering drugs has been suggested, using very small chemical building blocks, known as \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfragments\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. The first drug formed from fragments to be approved for cancer treatment appeared in 2011 with more on the horizon. Are fragments the key to beating cancer?

The Lunchtime Lecture series takes place Fridays, 12-1pm at the Leicester Adult Education College, located at 2 Wellington St, near the city end of New Walk. The lectures are delivered by current University of Leicester postgraduates and are open to the public, so there is no need to book, just come along on the day.

For more information please contact cjn10@leicester.ac.uk

    ]]>     No publisher pt91 Magazine:Staff College:MedBioPsych Event:Lecture 2015-03-11T16:30:00Z UoL Event     'New Frontiers in Forensics: Innovation and interdisciplinarity 30 years from Jeffreys' eureka moment' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/april/new-frontiers-in-forensics-innovation-and-interdisciplinarity-30-years-from-jeffreys-eureka-moment Henry Wellcome Building (Frank & Katherine May Lecture Theatre) - 15 Apr 2015, 09:00AM - 4:30PM In celebration of the 30th anniversary of the landmark discovery and application of DNA fingerprinting, the University of Leicester invites researchers and practitioners to attend a conference sharing new innovations in forensic science, spanning novel technologies, emerging methods and inter-disciplinary research. This is an event for practitioners, researchers and industrialists to explore the latest research and develop thinking to take professional practice forward. The latest innovations and expertise from across the Alec Jeffreys Forensic Science Institute are included, covering DNA, cold case investigation, violent crime and forensic pathology, and fingerprints. There is no registration fee, but booking is required.

    ]]>     No publisher pt91 Magazine:Staff Event:Conference College:SciEng Magazine:Research College:MedBioPsych 2015-04-15T08:00:00Z UoL Event     Cafe Sci Reborn https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/cafe-sci-reborn The Exchange, 50 Rutland Street, Leicester LE1 1RD - 23 Mar 2015, 06:15PM - 08:15PM Join us for Leicester's Cafe Sci Reborn at The Exchange for a lively chat on healthcare incentives. Should we reward or even pay people to lose weight, stop smoking, or get moving?

    Dr Gary O'Donovan of the University of Leicester will give a brief presentation before taking questions. There will then be a focus group to discuss the design of a research project. Gary's research is about physical activity and health. He works at the Leicester Diabetes Centre, which is part of the NIHR Leicester-Loughborough Diet, Lifestyle and Physical Activity Biomedical Research Unit.

    Come and join us! There's no charge, except your bar tab. Booking is not essential but it will help if you let us know you are coming on rp237@le.ac.uk.

    ]]>     No publisher User Submitted Magazine:Research College:MedBioPsych Magazine:Staff Event:Lecture 2015-03-23T18:15:00Z UoL Event     'Bike Lounge' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/bike-lounge St Martin's Coffee Shop, St Martin's Square, Leicester - 12 Mar 2015, 07:00PM - 10:00PM No publisher User Submitted College:MedBioPsych Event:Lecture Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research 2015-03-12T19:00:00Z UoL Event 'Researching and Reforming Unfitness to Plead' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/researching-and-reforming-unfitness-to-plead Frank & Katherine May Lecture Theatre, Henry Wellcome - 19 Mar 2015, 03:00PM - 04:00PM Professor Ronnie Mackay will present a talk as part of the Invited Speakers' Series on Thursday 19th March from 3-4pm in the Frank & Katherine May Lecture Theatre, Henry Wellcome.

    ]]>     No publisher User Submitted Magazine:Research Event:Lecture Magazine:Staff College:MedBioPsych 2015-03-19T15:00:00Z UoL Event     'Next-generation sequencing: local experience, platforms and projects' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/next-generation-sequencing-local-experience-platforms-and-projects FKMLT HWB - 11 Mar 2015, 13:50PM - 04:50PM This half-day workshop will present experience from users of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds various Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) platforms, including Illumina MiSeq, IonTorrent and Nanopore MinION. These platforms differ in their run costs, sample requirements, library preparation protocols, outputs, read-lengths, error-profiles and bioinformatic requirements.

    If you are interested in using these technologies please come along and discuss your projects with the speakers, and the staff of NUCLEUS, the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Genomics Core facility.

    ]]>     No publisher User Submitted Magazine:Staff College:MedBioPsych Magazine:Research Event:Courses 2015-03-11T13:50:00Z UoL Event     'Genetic admixture and host-pathogen interactions in Helicobacter pylori susceptibility' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/genetic-admixture-and-host-pathogen-interactions-in-helicobacter-pylori-susceptibility Astley Clarke Ground Floor Lecture Theatre - 17 Mar 2015, 12:00PM - 01:00PM Dr Sandra Beleza will be presenting a seminar entitled "Genetic admixture and host-pathogen interactions in Helicobacter pylori susceptibility" as part of the Microbial Science Theme seminar series.

    The seminar will be at 12pm on Tuesday 17th March in the Astley Clarke Ground Floor Lecture Theatre.

    \ufffd\ufffd

    ]]>     No publisher User Submitted Magazine:Staff Event:Lecture Magazine:Research College:MedBioPsych 2015-03-17T12:00:00Z UoL Event     Educate to Eradicate FGM (#e2e_FGM) https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/educate-to-eradicate-fgm-e2e_fgm College Court, Knighton Road, Leicester, LE2 3UF - 06 Mar 2015, 09:30AM - 04:30PM Female genital mutilation (FGM), also known as female genital cutting (FGC), is a controversial procedure that involves partial or total removal of the external female genitalia or other non-medical injury to the female genital organs.

    FGM is internationally recognized as a violation of the human rights of girls and women, and is a form of child abuse as it denies women and young girls security and personal liberty, privacy and bodily integrity, freedom of conscience and the right to good health and well-being. The personal consequences of FGM include physical, emotional and psychological trauma for those who survive and can also lead to death due to haemorrhage or infection, including tetanus, and shock.

    Although FGM is normally practised in many countries in Africa, Asia and the Middle East, it is no longer restricted to these geographical areas due to increasing globalisation. In the UK, it has been estimated that over 20,000 girls under the age of 15 are at risk of FGM each year, and that 66,000 women in the UK are living with the consequences of FGM.

    In 2011 Eva Organization for Women (EOW-Charity) in collaboration with the University of Leicester hosted its first impactnational FGM Conference at the University of Leicester; this was a resounding success in bringing together community leaders and religious scholars, health professionals and legal practitioners and victims of this illegal but still practised tradition to raise awareness.

    Again, EOW-Charity is hosting a symposium on Friday 6 March 2015 at the University of Leicester which will provide a unique opportunity to gain invaluable perspective, insight and best practice and understanding of the current framework of FGM. This symposium will also highlight the importance of three dimensional approaches (community leaders/religious scholars, professional practitioners and local authors) which needs to be strengthened in order to ensure better awareness, early intervention and prevention of FGM, so that together we help these who really need our support. We at EOW believe that education is the way forward to eradicate FGM; therefore, in this symposium we are also launching an educational package for both professionals and communities alike.

    ]]>     No publisher User Submitted College:SocSci College:MedBioPsych Magazine:Research Event:Conference Magazine:Staff 2015-03-06T09:30:00Z UoL Event     'An update on therapeutic aerosols: within and beyond the lungs' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/an-update-on-therapeutic-aerosols-within-and-beyond-the-lungs Clinical Education Centre, Glenfield Hospital - 20 Mar 2015, 01:00PM - 02:00PM Department of Respiratory Medicine, Allergy & Thoracic Surgery University Hospitals of Leicester Institute of Lung Health

    Dr Omar Usmani, Royal Brompton Hospital, London, will present a seminar on Friday 20th March 1300-1400.

    Lunch will be provided in the CEC Lounge at 1230. Everyone is welcome

    ]]>     No publisher User Submitted Magazine:Staff Event:Lecture Magazine:Research College:MedBioPsych 2015-03-20T13:00:00Z UoL Event     Unveiling of the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdInspirational Women at Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd gallery https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/unveiling-of-the-2018inspirational-women-at-leicester2019-gallery Garendon Room, 4th Floor Charles Wilson - 11 Mar 2015, 12:30PM - 01:30PM This year, for the first time, a series of events are being planned to celebrate International Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Day. The main event will be the unveiling of the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdInspirational Women at Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd gallery. This will take place on: Wednesday 11th March from 12.30pm - 1.30pm in the Ogden Lewis Suite, Fielding Johnson South Wing Basement.

    Speakers: Professor Paul Boyle, Dr Angela Lennox

    This event will also see the launch of the new women@Leicester webpages and the official launch of the women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds forum. Please do come along to this as it would be great to have a good turnout.
